message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Understanding Large-Language Model (LLM)-powered Human-Robot Interaction
Paper Abstract: Large-language models (LLMs) hold significant promise in improving\nhuman-robot interaction, offering advanced conversational skills and\nversatility in managing diverse, open-ended user requests in various tasks and\ndomains. Despite the potential to transform human-robot interaction, very\nlittle is known about the distinctive design requirements for utilizing LLMs in\nrobots, which may differ from text and voice interaction and vary by task and\ncontext. To better understand these requirements, we conducted a user study (n\n= 32) comparing an LLM-powered social robot against text- and voice-based\nagents, analyzing task-based requirements in conversational tasks, including\nchoose, generate, execute, and negotiate. Our findings show that LLM-powered\nrobots elevate expectations for sophisticated non-verbal cues and excel in\nconnection-building and deliberation, but fall short in logical communication\nand may induce anxiety. We provide design implications both for robots\nintegrating LLMs and for fine-tuning LLMs for use with robots.\n
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's information about large language models:

## Definition

A large language model (LLM) is a language model trained with self-supervised machine learning on a vast amount of text, designed for natural language processing tasks, especially language generation.

## Capabilities and Architecture

The largest and most capable LLMs are generative pre-trained transformers (GPTs) and provide the core capabilities of modern chatbots.(no content)They consist of billions to trillions of parameters and operate as general-purpose sequence models, generating, summarizing, translating, and reasoning over text.

## Training and Use

LLMs can be fine-tuned for specific tasks or guided by prompt engineering. However, these models acquire predictive power regarding syntax, semantics, and ontologies inherent in human language corpora, but they also inherit inaccuracies and biases present in the data they are trained on.

## Recent Developments

Since 2023, many LLMs have been trained to be multimodal, having the ability to also process or generate other types of data, such as images, audio, or 3D meshes. Additionally, open-weight LLMs have increasingly shaped the field since 2023, contributing to broader participation in AI development and greater transparency in model evaluation.

Sheridan - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_B._Sheridan"},{"title":"hitchBOT - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HitchBOT"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of Human-robot interaction based on the search results:

## Definition and Scope

Human–robot interaction (HRI) is the study of interactions between humans and robots.(no content)Human–robot interaction is a multidisciplinary field with contributions from human–computer interaction, artificial intelligence, robotics, natural language processing, design, psychology and philosophy.

## Key Research Areas

Human–robot interaction prioritizes the safety of humans that interact with potentially dangerous robotics equipment.(no content)The subfield of physical human–robot interaction (pHRI) has largely focused on device design to enable people to safely interact with robotic systems, but is increasingly developing algorithmic approaches in an attempt to support fluent and expressive interactions between humans and robotic systems.

## Applications and Goals

Goals in HRI range from industrial manufacturing through Cobots, medical technology through rehabilitation, autism intervention, and elder care devices, entertainment, human augmentation.(no content)Industrial applications of human-robot collaboration involve Collaborative Robots, or cobots, that physically interact with humans in a shared workspace to complete tasks such as collaborative manipulation or object handovers.

## Technology Development

Although initially robots in the human–robot interaction field required some human intervention to function, research has expanded this to the extent that fully autonomous systems are now far more common than in the early 2000s. Autonomous systems include from simultaneous localization and mapping systems which provide intelligent robot movement to natural-language processing and natural-language generation systems which allow for natural, human-esque interaction.

Human-robot interaction continues to evolve with increasing focus on safety, emotional intelligence, and socially appropriate interactions between humans and robots.

Web search results for query: "Body language non-verbal communication"

Links: [{"title":"Body language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Body_language"},{"title":"Nonverbal communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonverbal_communication"},{"title":"Body-to-body communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Body-to-body_communication"},{"title":"Communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communication"},{"title":"Nonverbal influence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonverbal_influence"},{"title":"Gesture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gestural"},{"title":"Conversation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discussion"},{"title":"Category talk:Nonverbal communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category_talk:Nonverbal_communication"},{"title":"Category:Nonverbal communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Nonverbal_communication"},{"title":"Unconscious communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unconscious_communication"}]

I've completed the web search for "Body language non-verbal communication." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

Body language is a type of nonverbal communication in which physical behaviors, as opposed to words, are used to express or convey information.(no content)Such behavior includes facial expressions, body posture, gestures, eye movement, touch and the use of space.(no content)Nonverbal communication is the transmission of messages or signals through a nonverbal platform such as eye contact, body language, social distance, touch, voice, physical environments/appearance, and use of objects.

## Importance and Impact

Scholars argue that nonverbal communication can convey more meaning than verbal communication.(no content)In face to face conversation it has been suggested that 85% of the communication is non-verbal/body language – a smile, a frown, a shrug, tone of voice conveying much added meaning to the mere words.

## Components of Body Language

Facial expression is an important part of body language and the expression of emotion. It can comprise movement of the eyes, eyebrows, lips, nose and cheeks. Additionally, facial expressions are a powerful medium for conveying emotions, sometimes even through subtle microexpressions. These microexpressions are fleeting, involuntary facial movements that briefly reveal genuine feeling.

## Cultural Differences

The use body language and nonverbal communication is very different across cultures and ethnic groups and only few nonverbal gestures have the same or a similar meaning universally.

Body language is a type of nonverbal communication in which physical behaviors, as opposed to words, are used to express or convey information.(no content)Such behavior includes facial expressions, body posture, gestures, eye movement, touch and the use of space.(no content)Nonverbal communication is the transmission of messages or signals through a nonverbal platform such as eye contact, body language, social distance, touch, voice, physical environments/appearance, and use of objects.

## Importance and Impact

Scholars argue that nonverbal communication can convey more meaning than verbal communication.(no content)In face to face conversation it has been suggested that 85% of the communication is non-verbal/body language – a smile, a frown, a shrug, tone of voice conveying much added meaning to the mere words.

## Components of Body Language

Facial expression is an important part of body language and the expression of emotion. It can comprise movement of the eyes, eyebrows, lips, nose and cheeks. Additionally, facial expressions are a powerful medium for conveying emotions, sometimes even through subtle microexpressions. These microexpressions are fleeting, involuntary facial movements that briefly reveal genuine feeling.

## Cultural Differences

The use body language and nonverbal communication is very different across cultures and ethnic groups and only few nonverbal gestures have the same or a similar meaning universally.

I found comprehensive information about Conversational AI. Here's an overview:

## What is Conversational AI?

Conversational AI through a conversational user interface (CUI) is a user interface for computers that emulates a conversation with a human.(no content)Instead of traditional command-based interfaces, CUIs allow users to communicate with computers in natural language, using natural language processing (NLP) to enable computers to understand, analyze, and create meaning from human language.

## Key Technologies

Modern chatbots typically use generative artificial intelligence systems that are capable of maintaining a conversation with a user in natural language and simulating the way a human would behave as a conversational partner.(no content)Natural language understanding (NLU) allows conversational interfaces to handle unstructured inputs such as spelling mistakes, and enables context to carry forward—for example, if a user asks about the population of the United States and then asks "Who is the president?", the search will carry forward that context.

## Applications

There are two main categories of conversational interfaces: voice assistants and chatbots.(no content)Conversational AI is used in conversational commerce through various means including live support on e-commerce websites, online chat using messaging apps, chatbots on messaging apps or websites, and voice assistants.(no content)A major area where chatbots have long been used is customer service and support, with various sorts of virtual assistants.

## Modern Examples

Chatbots have increased in popularity as part of the AI boom of the 2020s, with the popularity of ChatGPT, followed by competitors such as Gemini, Claude and later Grok.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "User study research methodology"

Links: [{"title":"User research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User_research"},{"title":"Usability testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usability_testing"},{"title":"User experience evaluation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User_experience_evaluation"},{"title":"Diary studies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diary_studies"},{"title":"Think aloud protocol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Think_aloud_protocol"},{"title":"User experience design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User_experience_design"},{"title":"User experience - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User_experience"},{"title":"User-centered design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User-centered_design"},{"title":"User analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User_analysis"},{"title":"Research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Research"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of user study research methodology:

## Overview

The user research process follows a traditional iterative design approach that is common to user-centered design and design thinking.

## Types of Research

User research is typically categorized in several ways:

**Generative vs. Descriptive Research:** Generative research or exploratory research is done to understand and define the problems to solve for users in the first place. It can be used during the initial stages of product development to create new solutions or it can be applied to an existing product to identify improvements and enhancements.(no content)Interviews, observational studies, secondary research, etc., are some of the common methods used during this phase.

**Attitudinal vs. Behavioral:** The Nielsen Norman group has provided a framework to better understand when to use which method. Attitudinal research is used to study users' perceptions, beliefs, opinions and what they think about a certain product or problem.(no content)Whereas, behavioral research measures how people really use a product.

**Qualitative vs. Quantitative:** Qualitative research help generate data by asking users about their attitudes through open ended questions via surveys, interviews, and observing behaviors directly.(no content)Quantitative research aims to measure attitudes and behaviors via surveys and analytics. Quantitative research typically use mathematical analysis where the instrument of data collection gathers data that can be coded numerically whereas in qualitative research analysis is not mathematical.

## Common Methods

Requirements are noted and refined through investigative methods including: ethnographic study, contextual inquiry, prototype testing, usability testing and other methods. Generative methods may also be used including: card sorting, affinity diagramming and participatory design sessions.

Here are the search results for "Robot":

## Definition and Overview

A robot is a machine—especially one programmable by a computer—capable of carrying out a complex series of actions automatically.(no content)A robot can be guided by an external control device, or the control may be embedded within.

## Types and Applications

Robots can be autonomous or semi-autonomous and range from humanoids such as Honda's Advanced Step in Innovative Mobility (ASIMO) and TOSY's TOSY Ping Pong Playing Robot (TOPIO) to industrial robots, medical operating robots, patient assist robots, dog therapy robots, collectively programmed swarm robots, UAV drones such as General Atomics MQ-1 Predator, and even microscopic nanorobots.

## Robotics Field

The branch of technology that deals with the design, construction, operation, and application of robots, as well as computer systems for their control, sensory feedback, and information processing is robotics.

## History

The term "robot" was first used in a play published by the Czech Karel Čapek in 1920. R.U.R. (Rossum's Universal Robots) was a satire, robots were manufactured biological beings that performed all unpleasant manual labor. According to Čapek, the word was created by his brother Josef from the Czech word robota 'corvée', or in Slovak 'work' or 'labor'.

The search results provide information on the definition of robots, their various types and applications, the field of robotics, and the historical origins of the term "robot."

Links: [{"title":"Robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot"},{"title":"I, Robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I,_Robot"},{"title":"Robot series - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_series"},{"title":"Android (robot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Android_(robot)"},{"title":"History of robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_robots"},{"title":"Mr. Robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mr._Robot"},{"title":"The Robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Robots"},{"title":"List of Robot Wars robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Robot_Wars_robots"},{"title":"List of fictional robots and androids - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_fictional_robots_and_androids"},{"title":"Rise of the Robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rise_of_the_Robots"}]

Here are the search results for "Robot":

## Definition and Overview

A robot is a machine—especially one programmable by a computer—capable of carrying out a complex series of actions automatically.(no content)A robot can be guided by an external control device, or the control may be embedded within.

## Types and Applications

Robots can be autonomous or semi-autonomous and range from humanoids such as Honda's Advanced Step in Innovative Mobility (ASIMO) and TOSY's TOSY Ping Pong Playing Robot (TOPIO) to industrial robots, medical operating robots, patient assist robots, dog therapy robots, collectively programmed swarm robots, UAV drones such as General Atomics MQ-1 Predator, and even microscopic nanorobots.

## Robotics Field

The branch of technology that deals with the design, construction, operation, and application of robots, as well as computer systems for their control, sensory feedback, and information processing is robotics.

## History

The term "robot" was first used in a play published by the Czech Karel Čapek in 1920. R.U.R. (Rossum's Universal Robots) was a satire, robots were manufactured biological beings that performed all unpleasant manual labor. According to Čapek, the word was created by his brother Josef from the Czech word robota 'corvée', or in Slovak 'work' or 'labor'.

The search results provide information on the definition of robots, their various types and applications, the field of robotics, and the historical origins of the term "robot."


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name, relation, entity_type, wikipedia_url, relevance.

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

Based on the search results, here's information about Human-Robot Interaction from Wikipedia:

## Overview

Human-robot interaction (HRI) goals range from industrial manufacturing through cobots, medical technology through rehabilitation, autism intervention, and elder care devices, to entertainment and human augmentation.

## Safety and Autonomy

Human-robot interaction prioritizes the safety of humans that interact with potentially dangerous robotics equipment.(no content)Initially, robots in the human-robot interaction field required some human intervention to function, but research has expanded to the extent that fully autonomous systems are now far more common, including systems with natural-language processing that allow for natural, human-esque interaction.

## Types of Robots

Robots in the human-robot interaction field are not limited to human-like robots; Paro and Kismet are both robots designed to elicit emotional response from humans, and so fall into the category of human-robot interaction.

## Research Focus

The subfield of physical human-robot interaction (pHRI) has focused on device design to enable people to safely interact with robotic systems, and is increasingly developing algorithmic approaches to support fluent and expressive interactions, with research focusing on both the safest physical interaction and socially correct interaction dependent on cultural criteria.(no content)The ACM/IEEE International Conference on Human-Robot Interaction is an annual conference focusing on human-robot interaction with roots in robotics, psychology, cognitive science, human computer interaction, human factors, artificial intelligence, organizational behavior, anthropology, and other fields.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name, relation, entity_type, wikipedia_url, relevance.

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

## Analysis Complete ✅

I've successfully analyzed the paper "Understanding Large-Language Model (LLM)-powered Human-Robot Interaction" and created a comprehensive triple extraction with the following results:

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (the paper presents empirical user study findings and design implications)

**Extracted Triples (6 total):**

1. **Large language model** (artifact, uses) - The core technology being integrated into robots for conversational capabilities
2. **Human-robot interaction** (task, uses) - The primary research domain examining human-robot interactions
3. **Chatbot** (artifact, uses) - The conversational AI architecture underlying LLM-powered robot interaction
4. **Robot** (tool, uses) - The physical platforms augmented with LLM capabilities
5. **User research** (method, proposes) - The user study (n=32) the paper conducts
6. **Nonverbal communication** (concept, uses) - The sophisticated non-verbal cues that LLM-powered robots need to execute

- Paper type correctly set
- All 6 triples have valid Wikipedia URLs
